facts.text: On 12th October, 1951, five candidates (respondents 1 to 5) were duly nominated for election to the Legislative Assembly of Himachal Pradesh for Rohru Constituency in Mahasu District.
On 30th November, 1951, first respondent (Sri Padam Dev) declared elected, having secured largest number of votes.
Result published in Official Gazette on 20th December, 1951.
On 14th February, 1952, Gyan Singh (fifth respondent), unsuccessful candidate, filed Election Petition No. 14 of 1952 challenging validity of first respondent's election.
On 4th August, 1952, Gyan Singh applied to withdraw petition; permitted by Tribunal order dated 20th September, 1952.
Appellant, an elector in Rohru Constituency, applied to be brought on record as petitioner; ordered on 21st November, 1952.

Charges in petition: (1) Sri Padam Dev interested in contracts for supply of Ayurvedic medicines to Government, disqualified under section 7(d) of Act No. XLIII of 1951. (2) Procured assistance of Government servants: Daulataram (proposer, post office servant), Motiram (seconder, post office servant), Sital Singh (extra-departmental agent, appointed polling agent at Arhal booth).

Election Tribunal by judgment dated 25th September, 1953 (appeal from order dated 23rd May, 1953), held: section 7(d) not applicable to Part C States; no proof of subsisting contracts on nomination date; section 123(8) not prohibiting proposing/seconding by Govt servants; point on Sital Singh not raised in petition. Petition dismissed.
Special leave to appeal granted by Supreme Court on 25th January, 1954.
Mandi contract: goods supplied and price received in September, 1951.
Mahasu contract: Government order placed 19th November, 1951; goods supplied December 1951 and January 1952.
Sirmur contract: Government order 25th September, 1951; goods supplied 1st December, 1951; letters/telegram from respondent 31st October, 27th November, 30th November 1951.
Appellant before Tribunal took stand that crucial date for subsisting contract was 12th October 1951 (nomination date).
Sital Singh did nothing beyond acting as polling agent.

legal_issues.text: Whether Sri Padam Dev disqualified under section 7(d) of Act No. XLIII of 1951 for being chosen to Legislative Assembly by reason of contracts for supply of Ayurvedic medicines to Himachal Pradesh Government, via section 17 of Act No. XLIX of 1951 incorporating Article 102(1)(e) of Constitution.

Whether Sri Padam Dev procured assistance of Government servants in contravention of section 123(8) of Act No. XLIII of 1951 by having Daulataram and Motiram subscribe nomination paper and Sital Singh as polling agent.

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 7(d) of Act XLIII/1951 applies via section 17 Act XLIX/1951 and Article 102(1)(e); contracts subsisting at material date (nomination or up to declaration/publication); contracts with Central Government via Articles 239, 77 as Part C States administered by President.
Procured assistance of Govt servants u/s 123(8): proposer/seconder and polling agent appointments.
Tribunal erred on subsisting contract (even if goods delivered, price due keeps it alive) and material period (nomination to gazette publication).
Appointment of Sital Singh as polling agent per se contravenes s.123(8); pure question of law, open despite not specifically raised.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Act XLIII/1951 s.123(8),46; Rules r.12, Form 6; s.128

respondent_arguments.text: Act XLIII/1951 s.7(d) not proprio vigore applicable to Part C States; s.17 Act XLIX/1951 requires disqualification under law made by Parliament directly; Part II (incl s.7) omitted from extension u/s.8 Act XLIX.
Even if applicable, contracts with State Govt (Himachal Pradesh via Chief Commissioner), not Central Govt; s.9(1)(a) defines appropriate Govt as Central for Parliament disqualification.
No subsisting contracts on nomination date; acceptance/dispatch post-nomination.

court_reasoning.text: S.17 Act XLIX incorporates disqualifications under Art.102(1)(e) incl s.7(d) Act XLIII as law by Parliament; not limited by s.8 omission of Part II, as s.17/7 cover qualifications/disqualifications directly; no inconsistency.
court_reasoning.key_observation: What disqualifies for Parliament membership disqualifies for State Assembly under s.17.

court_reasoning.text: Contracts with Part C State (via Chief Commissioner) not with Central Govt; President under Art.239 acts as State head, not Central; s.38(2) Act XLIX requires State executive in Chief Commissioner's name.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Part C States not merged with Central Govt.

court_reasoning.text: No proof of subsisting contracts with Central Govt; factual findings on specific contracts stand, appellant bound by concession on crucial date (nomination). Tribunal errors on law do not affect conclusions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant cannot change case on facts at appeal stage.

court_reasoning.text: S.123(8) does not prohibit Govt servant proposing/seconding nomination (s.33(2) privilege); follows Rai Krushna Bose v. Binod Kanungo.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Privilege under s.33(2) not taken away.

court_reasoning.text: Appointment of Govt servant as polling agent (s.46, r.12) not per se contravention of s.123(8); duties (identify voters, s.128 secrecy) do not further prospects without more; no abuse proved.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mere appointment without exploitation not infringement.

holdings.text: S.7(d) Act XLIII/1951 applies to Part C State elections via s.17 Act XLIX/1951 and Art.102(1)(e), but requires contract with Central Govt for Parliament disqualification analogue.
Govt servant proposing/seconding nomination or acting as polling agent does not per se contravene s.123(8) absent furtherance of prospects.

precedents_cited.relevance: Contract subsists if price due post-delivery; disqualification from nomination to declaration (though obiter here)

precedents_cited.case_name: Rai Krushna Bose v. Binod Kanungo
precedents_cited.relevance: S.33(2) confers privilege on electoral roll persons to propose/second; s.123(8) does not take it away

statutes_cited.relevance: Disqualifications for contracts; corrupt practice of procuring Govt servant assistance; appointment of polling agents

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951 (Act No. XLIX of 1951)
statutes_cited.relevance: Qualifications/disqualifications for Part C States; extension of parts of Act XLIII; electoral rolls; executive action

statutes_cited.relevance: Disqualifications for Parliament; administration of Part C States by President/Chief Commissioner

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People (Conduct of Elections and Election Petitions) Rules, 1951

outcome.summary: Appeal against Election Tribunal's dismissal of petition challenging Sri Padam Dev's election dismissed; no disqualification under s.7(d) as contracts not with Central Govt; no contravention of s.123(8) by Govt servants' roles.

key_quotes.text: "What it does enact is that if a person would be disqualified to be chosen to either House under an Act of Parliament, he would be disqualified to be chosen for the State Assembly."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core interpretation of s.17 Act XLIX

key_quotes.text: "The President who is the executive head of the Part C States is not functioning as the executive head of the Central Government, but as the head of the State under powers specifically vested in him under article 239."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes Central vs State contracts in Part C

key_quotes.text: "So long as the polling agent confines himself to his work as such agent of merely identifying the voters, it cannot be said that section 123(8) has, in any manner, been infringed."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits scope of s.123(8) for polling agents
